title: The Palmetto Cluster
text:
The Palmetto Cluster is a group of computers on Clemson’s campus. These computers are much more powerful than your laptop or even desktops in the lab.
Running computational chemistry calculations requires the use of these powerful computers. For research, you will log into the Palmetto Cluster remotely.

title: The Palmetto Cluster
text:
The Palmetto Cluster is a group of computers on Clemson’s campus. These computers are much more powerful than your laptop or even desktops in the lab.
Running computational chemistry calculations requires the use of these powerful computers. For research, you will log into the Palmetto Cluster remotely.

title: The Palmetto Cluster
text:
Logging in

Open your termial (Terminal on Macs, PowerShell on Windows)
Type ssh [username]@slogin.palmetto.clemson.edu
Enter your password

This logs you in to a computer called the “login node”. “Node” is a computing term for a single computational unit within a cluster of computers.

title: The Palmetto Cluster
text:
Directory Structure and Creating Files
Just as your laptop has folders and files, you can create folders and files on Palmetto. In computing, folders are called directories.

Make a new directory to store your tutorials.
mkdir tutorials
To check your work, type ls to list all directories and files. You should see tutorials.
Make a file in the tutorials directory. First, move into that directory.
cd tutorials
What would you see if you typed ls here? Try it to check your understanding.
To open a new file called my_file, type
vim my_file
This opens a new file with an editor called vim.
To write in this file, press a for append. Then begin typing a phrase.
Once you have finished typing, press esc to leave editing mode.
To save and close your file, type :wq. w is for write (or save) and q is for quit.

title: The Palmetto Cluster
text:
Check your understanding


If you were to type ls here, what would you see?

No files A file named my_file



Now, let’s add to the file. Paste the following text into my_file. To paste, open the file, type a, and right-click paste. Save and close using :wq.
There are a few options for viewing the contents of this file.


Use cat to view all contents. cat my_file
Use tail to view the end of the file. tail my_file
Use head to view the beginning of the file. head my_file


Insert vim tutorial

title: website
text:
This is a Quarto website.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: Aerosols
text:
DFT Optimizations
To start, make sure all xyz files from configurational sampling are in folders GA/20K, GA/20K-1, GA/200K, GA/PM7, etc.
At the same level as GA, make the directories QM/wb97xd-ultrafine. Copy all uniqueStructures-*.data files to wb97xd-ultrafine/.
Within wb97xd-ultrafine, run opt_wb97xd.py uniqueStructures-PM7.data -h to see options for submission.
Once you are ready, run the command with your options set. Then, run sbatch run_gaussian.slurm to submit all jobs listed in the com_list.txt file.
Confirm that all optimizations have completed by running check_opts.py. Any files that terminated early due to wall time limits will be printed to the screen.
To rerun these, you can either:

sbatch --array=17,33 run_gaussian.slurm using the array number of the jobs that need to be rerun.
Update com_list.txt to include only the jobs that need rerunning.

Wait for these jobs to finish, then run check_opts.py one more time to ensure that all optimizations have completed.

title: Aerosols
text:
Determine Unique Structures
getRotConsts-wb97xd.csh
similarityAnalysis.py uf rotConstsData_C

title: Aerosols
text:
DLPNO Single Point Energies
Make a directory within QM/wb97xd-ultrafine called dlpno.
Copy uniqueStructures-uf.data to dlpno/. Move into dlpno, and edit the dlpno/uniqueStructures-uf.data to include only the files with relative energies within 6-8 kcal/mol. (If you are unsure, consult someone.)
Run make_dlpno_inps.py to generate DLPNO-CCSD(T) input files and the slurm script. This script has the following options:









Flag
Default
Description
Options




--aug
--aug=haug
augmentation type of basis set
haug, aug, or noaug


--zeta
--zeta=D,T,Q
basis set zeta-levels
D,T,Q,5,6


--nproc
--nproc=12
number of cores/processors
any integer (check freestd)


--mem
--mem=100g
amount of SLURM memory per job
any integer followed by g


--time
--time=24:00:00
wall time per job
hours:minutes:seconds


--constraint
--constraint=cpu_gen_cascadelake
CPU name
cpu_gen_broadwell, cpu_gen_sapphirerapids, cpu_gen_cascadelake, or none


--scratch
--scratch=shared
shared or local scratch
shared, local
